posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: Either way, Signal said they will not comply, period. Which means the UK will either have to forego enforcement for them, or block Signal (which is circumventable using proxies).

which is circumventable using proxies

Censorship is effective when it works for most people. Signal having proxies won‚Äôt help the vast majority.

Talya (she/her):

(also doesn‚Äôt signal detect when it blocks and tells you you should use a proxy? that should help as well)

Signal should create a centralized repository of Signal proxies and carefully distribute some of them to users like Tor does with bridges. Unlike Tor, which is unauthenticated, Signal could use account ownership to rate limit and prevent full enumeration of proxies. Domain fronting would be the ultimate solution if only hypocrite cloud providers hadn‚Äôt stopped it‚Äôs use.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: There are now newer methods that improve over domain fronting. Can‚Äôt remember what it was called.
Probably Refraction networking - Wikipedia but good luck convincing ISP to install decoy routers into their networks.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Not at all. It‚Äôs related to TLS. And DNS over TLS I believe. It utilizes new properties of TLS 1.3.

Found it. It‚Äôs called domain hiding.

ZDNET

DEF CON: New tool brings back 'domain fronting' as 'domain hiding'

After Amazon and Google stopped supporting the censorship-evading domain fronting technique on their clouds in 2018, new Noctilucent toolkit aims to bring it back in a new form as "domain hiding."

link_counts.title: DEF CON: New tool brings back 'domain fronting' as 'domain hiding' | ZDNET

posts.name: Jj
posts.cooked:
I see the article does mention Signal and Whatsapp, but at the same time it opens saying ‚ÄúSocial media firms‚Äù, Which Signal is not. It would fall under the P2P communication app.

I can see the argument being done for massive broadcast channels, just like what Whatsapp has implemented and are not E2EE and Signal does not have.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Signal can do mass broadcast channels and has been able to for a few years. The difference is they‚Äôre not easily discoverable.

posts.name: Jj
posts.cooked: I recall that Signal‚Äôs groups have a limit of 1000 members because of the E2E key exchange complexity, so it can‚Äôt grow to hundreds of thousands or millions like WA or Telegram channels, where people subscribe to the channel without having to have any contacts in common.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: I hope Signal‚Äôs limitation remains. By making communication from one person to millions so easy, it breeds authoritarianism, misinformation, and disinformation, and the damage of that is evident in now-backsliding democracies. It‚Äôs basically history repeating itself when the same was done in the WW2 era via the radio. Now, that ‚Äúradio‚Äù is a global broadcast rather than limited to a single country.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
WIRED UK ‚Äì 26 Oct 23

The UK‚Äôs Controversial Online Safety Act Is Now Law

The UK government says its Online Safety Act will protect people, particularly children, on the internet. Critics say it‚Äôs ineffective against dangerous misinformation and may be a threat to privacy.

link_counts.title: The UK‚Äôs Controversial Online Safety Act Is Now Law | WIRED UK

posts.cooked:
Given this bill has now passed and is an Act, have there been any updates from Signal on their current position on this matter and how they intend to handle this if Ofcom comes knocking insisting they break or weaken encryption to enable client-side scanning?

There is a lot of misinformation out there already on the likes of YouTube with people claiming to their followers that this Act marks the end of private messaging and E2EE in the UK, and that apps like Signal, WhatsApp (being specifically mentioned), etc will have no choice but to comply and start client-side scanning should they be ordered to.

With Signal being open source, I fail to see how this Act can end E2EE messaging as people are claiming. I don‚Äôt think these people understand that anyone can view, fork, build, and redistribute the software.

Some reassurances from Signal on their position and future plans would be good.

posts.cooked:
This officially became an Act only in the last week or so though.

I‚Äôm aware they said they would leave the UK etc previously, but that was when it was a Bill and had not fully been passed.

There don‚Äôt appear to be any statements or blog posts in the last week or so about this reaffirming their position.

It‚Äôs not so much that they would leave the UK, it‚Äôs that they will not comply with any demands the UK may make to compromise security.

If it got bad enough, they would just use the same anti-censorship proxies they use against other tyrannical governments.
